description:
1862: Second Manassas is the twentieth battle in the series and is the second in the North Virginia Campaign.

The Confederates under General Thomas J "Stonewall" Jackson are attempting to attack the Union supply line at Manassas Junction, the Union General John Pope must stop them.

The games comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

—description from the publisher

1862: Northern Virginia Campaign Pack

The full set of THREE battles within the North Virginia Campaign. 
The Confederates lead by General Robert E Lee are launching an attack across Northern Virginia against the Union Army under General John Pope.

The games comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

—description from the publisher

Gaines's Mill is the fourteenth battle in the series and is the fourth in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862.

The Confederates are following up the retiring Union forces on the north side of the Chicahominy River.

The game comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

—description from the publisher

In Bad Juju each player is one of the spirits from the Loa family. Your mission is to show devotion to the Bondye God by creating various spells. The Spirit that creates the most powerful spells by the end of the night will be granted superiority over the rest!

Bad Juju is a simple set collection card game with light bluffing and take-that.

2-5 Players will do this by playing cards, either within their spell area to complete sets, or within the discard pile to perform the action on the card. At times players will have to rely on their ability to bluff in order to obtain a "wild" card to try and complete their set.

This easy to learn game takes about 20 minutes to play, no matter the player count.

The player with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

Phalanx is a set of small to medium scale wargames rules for the Classical Ancient period of warfare between 800BC and 200AD.

For 6mm miniatures

scale: 
1 mini = 4 men
1 bound = 1 minute

The Prussians are defending Ligny against the first French attack of the Hundred Days War. 
Napoleon wants to crush the Prussians so that he can turn his full attention on the Allied forces around Brussels.

This game is Print and Play, it comes with a full set of Grand Empires Rules, a 2D or 3D Game Board, Counters and Battle Rules. If desired the game board can be constructed to form an amazing 3D contoured battlefield.

—description from the publisher

The 4 Xs of the traditional Civilisation game are:
eXplore.  eXploit.  eXpand.  eXterminate. By adding another option: eXcavate, 5X goes one better!
Outthink your rivals, call upon Great Leaders, build glorious Wonders and all in under half-an-hour; 5X challenges you to juggle actions and resources without letting your competition get too far ahead.
Can your Civilisation build a legacy for the ages?

5X is a simultaneous action selection game. Over seven rounds, players will use a limited range of cards to collect resources and build Wonders in order to gain the most Victory points at the end.

—description from the designer

WizBang! is a fast-paced card game where two players take part in a wizards' duel. In each round of the duel, a magical category is randomly rolled which is used to judge the spells used in that round. Players use the best spells they have available - or mix things up with Wizard cards, allowing them to change categories at will, or Randomizer cards, which force a random change. In addition to the spell cards they use through the round, players also have a few extra tricks up their sleeve - action cards that can be played at almost any point of the game.

Quick to learn and stuffed with 79 unique and wacky spells, WizBang! is a light, fun game of reckless magic.

—description from the designer

Pirates, homicidal robots, alien traders and marines in space.

Clash on the Fringe takes you back to the halcyon days of military space adventure, but through the lens of modern game design.

Designed to be playable with any miniatures in your collection, Clash on the Fringe plays quickly and with minimal record keeping.

Features include:

     Integrated turn sequence where both players act.
     Robust combat system that encourages tactical finesse.
     Reaction fire, psionics, leadership skills.
     Tools to build a wide variety of units, vehicles, 13 alien species, droid infantry and local wildlife.
     Scenario rules ranging from dangerous plant life to ice planets and wandering monsters.
     Fully featured points system or make your own scenario!
     A background setting that sits in the background. Use it when you want, adapt your own when you please.
     Consistent rules that apply to all units. Infantry, vehicles and monsters all follow the same basic concepts. You don't have to learn three different games at the same time.
     D100 tables for quick plot inspiration!


If you remember the days of early science fiction wargaming: Of exploring a universe filled with danger and excitement, of a time when everything did not have to be depressing and dark, when strange aliens could rub shoulders on the tabletop, Clash on the Fringe is for you.

Grab those dusty old miniatures that have sat abandoned for 20 years and give them a new life.

Just remember: Regret nothing!

—description from the publisher

New version of Skyjo which adds Action Cards and Joker Cards.

In Skyjo, each player 12 cards in a 3x4 pattern, two of them face up, all others hidden. On your turn you can take the top card from the discard or draw pile. You can exchange one card (hidden or open) from your display with it or discard the drawn card to turn one card face up. The round ends when one player has only open cards. All cards will be revealed, and the points added for each player (Cards are ranked from -2 to 12). The game ends when one player reaches 100 points or more. Whoever has the lowest score wins.
The trick is: Whenever one column of 3 cards all have the same value, the whole column is discarded, so if you are feeling lucky, you can try to collect sets of high cards (which everyone else will likely discard, so you can take them from the discard pile).

Skyjo Action adds (as the name suggests) Action Cards, which allow for special moves: Exchange cards in your tableau, Exchange cards between players, Steal an action card, Take two turns in a row etc. You get an action card whenever you put or reveal a Joker in your tableau, or you can take an Action Card instead of a normal move. Jokers allow for easier set collection and make very valuable sets in themselves (-10 or -15 points). 
As a new rule, rows of identical cards are now also discarded.

Whole Brain Exercise is won by answering more clues on a crossword than your opponents.  points are scored based on word length and the number of letters that you add.
Clues to the cross words come in 9 types
Anagram - letters to the answer are in the clue just in the wrong order
Hidden word - word is in the clue may span words
Charade - solution to the clue gives the answer in parts
Reversal - as per anagram but the word is in reverse
Homophones - answer is pronounced in the clue
Two definitions - one word corresponds to both parts of the clue
Container - word is broken into multiple parts.  one part is containedin the other part.
Deletion - gives clues of letters to remove from the clue in order to give a hidden word
Exchange - clue is in two parts with the last part being last in the clue.

—user summary

99 Fabulous excerpts from the chronicles of modern history and the word of music have been brought together to produce the ultimate music and general trivia quiz - ever.

A Cassette version of the original trivial pursuit.

—user summary

Win as many points as possible by "sealing the deal" with your opponents!  Use your knowledge of your opponents' trivia strengths and weakness to maximize your points haul.

Aim is to win 12 or more points.

Play goes in a clockwise direction the dealer reads out a question other players then indicate play or pass of the players who are playing the dealer selects one and tries to get an agreement as to how many points he will accept for the answer this is done out of 3.  If agreement is reached then if the question is answered correctly points are divided between dealer and player as agreed if answer is incorrect no pints are awarded and the deal moves on.

—user summary

In Maglev Metro, utilize state-of-the-art magnetic levitation technology to build a metropolitan rail system, transporting workers and robots beneath the city. Replace aging Manhattan and Berlin subway systems with newer, faster, quieter technology. Enhance your rail system's abilities so that your passengers arrive at their destinations first.

Efficiency is your key to success in this pick-up-and-deliver, tile-laying, engine-building game. Transparent tiles allow your route to overlap your opponents' tracks, winding you along from station to station. Robots efficiently upgrade and adjust your abilities, leveraging unique goals to maximize points. By the end of the game, the game board has morphed into a modern subway map, with brightly-colored routes connecting stations all over the city.

Maglev Metro contains two unique maps.

—description from the publisher

Game is won by the last player left in the game.
The game is started by a person reading out a piece of good news from the card and throwing a bean bag to another player.  This person must reverse the news (from good to bad or visa versa) and throw the sack to another person.  Player is out of the game if they hesitate. there statement is too long, the statement is not relevant to the last statement or is a repeat.

Play is limited to time or number of rounds

—user summary

It's sunny outside, let's go biking!

     pick 6 dice among the 18 available,
     roll them 3 times to get the required combinations from the track,
     move your little rider forward!


Let's gooooo!
Dicycle Race is an extremely simple, fast and completely addictive racing game!
With its 4 game modes, its 5 variants and its 3 scoring modes, it is fully modular and suited for the whole family!

—description from the publisher

The Napoleonic Wars are in full swing...

The familiar sight of long lines of scarlet-coated British infantry advance on their enemies, ready to shatter them with their disciplined volleys...

But wait.  The opposing soldiers are in line, not an attack column.  Some of them wear grey, not blue, and they speak English, albeit with a strange accent.

French-speaking troops are on the British side, decked in distinctive "habitant" dress.  On the flanks, buckskin-clad frontiersmen face off against painted Natives, both using tomahawks and scalping knives rather than bayonets.

These are not the ordered fields of Europe.  This is the wooded wilderness of North America, where artillery pieces are a rarity and cavalry almost non-existent.  Welcome to the Anglo-American war of 1812.  It's Napoleonics, but not as you know it...

A complete ruleset for recreating the War of 1812 on land in miniature, Whuppin' Jonathon allows you to refight the small-scale but desperate battles that saved Canada and established the United States as a respected world power.

Use of d10 dice exclusively.

Rules for infantry, cavalry, guns, howitzers, and rockets.  Sample battle to illustrate the game - the battle of Frenchtown.  Includes an easy to follow ready reference sheet.

—description from the publisher

Play the Seven Years’ War 1756-1763 is a project made possible by the great and beautiful collection of Gianpaolo Bistulfi, who in many years of modelling career has personally painted thousands of toy soldiers. Now these soldiers will be at your disposal to obtain, with little effort, entire armies of battalions of infantry, squadrons of cavalry, batteries of cannons, houses and buildings, trees and much more material needed to create the scenes of your battle.

We also explain tricks and modes for a good assembly of the pieces, as well as the official rules for playing wargame.

All in 50 pages full of hundreds of soldiers supplied in the standard scale of 25/28mm that you can, for personal use only, photocopy on thicker cardboard and thus get armed with the desired size.

So what are you waiting for? Wear the general commander’s shoulder pads, equip yourself with a capable table, a practical ruler to measure, a pair of dice and get ready to lead hundreds or thousands of armed in epic and exciting battles of history!

—description from the publisher

On the edge of a distant galaxy, life has been thriving in the solar system of the ancient star, Zohneth. After discovering their Sun was beginning the violent process of dying and their planets were in imminent danger, all alien races came together and invented the Kyur: a gravitational machine capable of stabilizing the vehement star. No one could have foreseen what happened next. The Kyur created an interdimensional bridge. Dimentals, invisible beings from a parallel universe, were released and are infecting the hearts and minds of these once peaceful species. War has begun.

Dimentals: Unseen Warfare is an expandable card game for 2 players. Players will select and collect resources and play cards onto the battlefield to protect their homeworld and attack their enemies. The game is played by turns and is expandable to up to 6 players.

Dimentals: Unseen Warfare features a unique Spectrum Shifted Blacklight Technology. The game includes exclusive card art and patented ink which glow in UV light. The ink is invisible in normal light so special hidden abilities and pictures come to life once the blacklight is activated. Special Dimentals cards are completely hidden from the players until revealed as well.

—description from the publisher

Eagles, Swords and Bayonets covers the period from 1790 to 1815 in Europe and Russia. The intent of these rules is speed of play and while trying to return the grand tactical flavor of the Napoleonic Wars.

ln the past we have played many rules for the Napoleonic period and have found them floundering just as the heat of the battle was getting interesting. Red tape, too many odd rules, all in the name of the realism. it is just too unbelievable for gaming.

So what we have done here, is sort through all the good, the bad and the ugly of all the rules we have played, and tried to come up with a set that will stay together when the real fighting starts.

Many rule sets have good qualities about them. What we have done here is try to take all those good thing and make a grand tactical miniature wargame out of them for 15mm to 20 mm figures. With little difficulty one can  adapt these rules to fit 6, 10, 25, 30 or 40 mm figures.

The rules are for grand tactical division and corps play although there is no reason you cannot use them for tactical regimental level games. 
Players do not need tons of dice just a few D-10 and D-6 dice will do. There is no writing of rules and most games can be played in three to four hours with resolution.

—description from the publisher

If you were picked on your entire life, would you consider finding a way to fight back?  In Kobolds Vs. Goblins that's what happens! When the leader of a small tribe of Kobolds has finally had enough of being picked on and ridiculed, he comes up with a plan.  Not just "a" plan, "the" plan!  If the ones picking on him are doing it because they are stronger and bigger than him, he'll find someone bigger and stronger than THEM!

It's a foolproof plan.  He decides to swear allegiance to the Mightiest of them all, the great red dragon.  But, he knows he can't just go alone.  The great red dragon wouldn't even bat an eye at a single Kobold seeking to join his ranks.  The plan calls for a much larger number of Kobolds to show up and wear their allegiance.  He isn't sure, but he thinks 30 sounds like a pretty large number.

So, the plan, to reiterate, is to recruit 30 Kobolds to join the cause and follow the great red dragon, then, make fun of all the ones that have made fun of us because we'll have the protection of the great red dragon!

This is the perfect plan, well it was!  Unfortunately, the Goblins (Another of the puny races that always gets picked on and our bitter rivals) heard about "the plan".  The Goblins have decided to copy the plan and only change one little detail... they are going to swear allegiance to the Great Orcish Chieftain!  How dare they steal the plan that took me the whole time I was on the poop pot!

The plan has changed, well, no, not really.  But now we have to do it faster than them!  Then, we'll have the great red dragon smoosh those little green meanies!

Oh, I've gone on a tangent haven't I?

Ahem...

You'll love the fast paced nature of Kobolds Vs. Goblins with the rapid dice rolls, the press-your-luck mechanics blended perfectly with Roll & Write tracking system for a sweet 5-15 minute game that you'll want to play again and again.

—description from the publisher

Become a hard-boiled private eye,
navigate through the dangerous "noir" world,
and find your destiny - maybe even your femme fatale!

In Game Noir, players become private detectives and have to decide wisely what to do with their action points as they move along the NOIR path. Unpredictable events occur there, the detectives may encounter the femme fatale, end up in the bar for a while, or chase the suspect. They gather black and white tokens they can use to cancel effects of unfavorable events. The tokens also determine to which final path (peace, justice, revenge) a player goes. Then they roll dice and earn victory points for achieving various endings (beware, death is one of them). Being the first to achieve an ending, having an alliance with the femme fatale and/or catching the suspect gives the players bonus points.

Printed components are: board (A4 or A3 format) and 80 tokens (2x A4). Rules have 4 pages. Additional components needed are: different-colored pawns (2-5 for detectives, 1 for femme fatale, 1 for a suspect, 1 spare pawn if possible) and 1-2 six-sided dice.

—description from the designer

Ever wondered what you'd look like as a vegetable, or with a huge beard? Find out in Drawsome People, a hilarious drawing game of side-splitting scribbles from Ridley's Games!

Draw famous celebrities, characters and your fellow players in this hilarious party game! With a huge range of famous faces to choose from, there's really no drawing talent required. Anyone can join in the fun and be doodling Drawsome People in no time!

Roll the dice at the beginning of each normal round to determine who everyone draws from their card, like a Mash Up combination of two people or Wedding where the player must draw the fictional nuptials of any two people on their card. Don't forget the bonus cards with challenges like drawing someone at the table as a vegetable! The person with the most points at the end of five rounds wins!

—description from the publisher

Fortunes Won and Lost allows you to adventure during the Age of Imperialism^. 
Explore the dark recesses of a steamy jungle. Lead a raid against enemy tribesmen. March in relief of a surrounded outpost. You can do this and more with Fortunes Won and Lost.

Why limit yourself to playing only historical games? This is a great period to make up your own countries and places to explore. ImagiNation gaming they call it. Draw up a rough map and put in a few villages. Toss in a fort or two and you’re good.

Inside you’ll find:

     Six Army Lists that can be adapted for any army of the Colonial Period.
     Rules for combat that work just as well for small skirmishes or big battles.
     A complete and easy to track campaign system to give meaning to your games.
     A variety of pre-generated games.
     A low bookkeeping system to track how well you are doing.
     Retirement rules to determine how you ended up after your career has ended.
     All this and much more.


Fortunes Won and Lost is an easy game to play, learn and teach. It’s easy, but it’s also fun. It’s easy, but it’s also a challenge. It’s great for when you want to spend less time setting up a game and more time playing it.

While all games “can” be played solo, although not always very well, Fortunes Won and Lost is designed for solo play or on the same side with your friends. The Artificial Intelligence creates a realistic enemy for you to fight where no two games will ever play the same. Welcome to…

FORTUNES WON AND LOST!

^The Age of Imperialism was the period between 1870 to 1914 that saw no less than eight European powers in conflict with each other and the native peoples that inhabited the lands of Africa and Asia to which these powers laid claim”.

—description from the publisher

The board game where you battle against the other Lords to spread your domain! Whether you choose to be defensive and build your castle one wall at a time or grow your army to control the area’s resources, your goal is to use your army of Archers, Foot Soldiers, Cavalry and Catapults and defeat the other would-be Lords to rule the realm!

Basic game contains full country battle field board, 32 miniature army pieces, 16 castle pieces, scenario card deck, resource tokens, army base counters and more – Over 150 pieces! Special: Contains unique turn/season dial – keep track of player turns and automatically move through the seasons!

Players choose one of four sides for your home township, North, South, East or West. Play as all humans or play as one of 4 additional races with the Race Add-On - Elves, Dwarves, Orcs or Undead. The four corners are reserved for the areas to find one of four resources; Ore Deposit (Iron), Forest (Wood), Granite Quarry (Stone) & Wild Game (Leather). The exact resource located in each corner is randomly determined once the players have chosen their sides. Players may need to decide early on if they will build offensively first by growing their army with iron, wood and leather, or build their castle with stone and wood. Your ultimate goal will be to build an army to overtake all of your opponents and rule the realm! The scenario card deck lets random encounters and events occur - Mercenaries could join your army or bug-infested logs means the loss of critical wood tokens.

Over 150 pieces, cast and printed in sturdy polyurethane/resin in 5 colors, depicting pieces of your castle and your army of Archers, Foot Soldiers, Cavalry, Catapults (2 each of all, per army) and more. As you grow your troops you add base counters to each army miniature to show the size of your force. Battle for the realm’s resources and take down your enemy’s castle. Easy to play and quick to set up – the 24”x 24” game board consists of nine 8”x 8” boards with a handy tray to keep all of your resource tokens and troop base counters separate. 24 dice (12 each of 2 colors) included!

Solo play with the 42 card AI deck and separate rules included. Kickstarter launches 2/13/20

—description from the publisher

In Avatar Spirits, you take control of a team of fighters. Use their attributes and skills to execute maneuvers and combat techniques, combining cards to perform devastating sequences to defeat your opponent.
Clash your way to victory, execute combat techniques and explore exciting combos in this fast paced and dynamic 1v1 showdown!
Avatar Spirits is a competitive fighting card game for two players, inspired by arcade fighting games. Featuring simultaneous action, dynamic turns, hand, resources and opportunity management.
The objective of the game is to reduce the opponent's will points (WP) to zero using cards from your hand and the skills of your avatar fighter. The first player to achieve it wins the game. 
You can build your own deck! Each new expansion comes with brand new fighters and strategies!

—description by publisher

Gridblock is an abstract card driven game, where players have to move on a tile grid and try to place markers in order to score victory points. Each player has a deck of six cards, which show a combination of movement points from 1 to 3 and one of six symbols. Markers may only be places, if the symbol on the played card matches the symbol on the tile their movement ends on. Bonus points may be scored if a player manages to place multiple markers on a single tile.

The game is played with the components of the Green Box of Games. The Meeple Mini Expansion is not needed to play this game.

Gridblock won the Best Original Game category of the 2018 Green Box of Games Design Contest.

The Age of Eagles 2nd Edition, aka Age of Eagles II (Napoleonic Fire & Fury) is a complete update of the original rules set and as such has spawned a French edition and expansion modules covering the Lace Wars and the Age of Rifles. Glossy color covers, BW interiors, same length as the previous, first edition.  The game is a massive evolution of the first Age of Eagles and includes:

•    Correction of all grammar, vocabulary and spelling errors.
•    Interpretations of rules integrated into the text of the document.
•    Rules changes, from both the author and our 3000 + person Yahoo Group added and integrated into the text of the book.
•    New rules and data charts, from both the author and the Yahoo Group added and integrated into the text of the document.
•    New army lists and generals, to include an all-new Ottoman army chart and a slew of Spanish generals.
•    Changes are easily identified by underlined text.

Like its predecessor, Age of Eagles II is based on Fire & Fury for the American Civil War. This is a BIG battle game where units are infantry and cavalry brigades, as well as artillery batteries of between 6 and 12 guns. Each infantry stand represents 360-foot soldiers while each cavalry stand represents 180 mounted troopers. Ground scale is 120 yards to each inch, while all game turns represent 30 minutes of actual time. Players command corps, not battalions, and engagements of 150,000 plus combatants are an easy gaming reality.

The complete AOE related product line is sold direct thru digital distribution, though hardcopy versions are available from certain retailers. AOE II is 96+ pages long. Kindle formatted products are sold exclusively thru Amazon, while digital downloads exportable to PDF format may be purchased via Google Play.

Online, public research portal for this game and its historical period (to include flags for miniatures, official histories, Public Domain military maps, images and publications - all copyright friendly and FREE to download) at https://tinyurl.com/AOE-Napoleonic-Research-Portal.

— description from the publisher

Each round in Shitty Questions, the active player asks the other players a question. After each reply, secretly drop the player's heart in one of two tubes: Smart or Shitty! The last responder chooses the winning tube. The players in the chosen tube move up the freedom board!

—description from the publisher

Chinese and English game based on the Chinese national epic novel Journey to the West.

Players move their monk, monkey, pigsy and Shaseng pieces from Chang An to Tianzhu (the ancient Chinese name for India) with rules similar to those of Pachisi. Play is made more interesting by inclusion of special powers for each type of piece which can affect each other type in special ways as well as cloud paths which a player may attempt to use to evade his enemies. There are also variant rules to change the victory conditions or play of the game.

Pieces are plastic with colored stickers with the board made from laminated paper.

—user summary

Koenig Krieg Version 4

This new edition allows players to not only re-fight battles during the wars of Frederick the Great, but also the Great Northern War, Napoleonic Wars, American Civil War, War of Triple Alliance, Mexican-American War, Zulu Wars, Crimean, Franco-Prussian and Austro-Prussian wars as well. It has taken a few years now of game testing and organising but we are finally there.

Inside the book:

     Clearly presented rules, easy to read with plenty of diagrams and examples.
     New and improved sequence of play, with detailed rules for command and control, movement, shooting, close combat, exploitation and morale.
     New Brigade Morale Rules.
     New Combined Action Rules.
     New Reaction Rules.
     New Village and Garrision Rules.


And much, much more!

So come on and play Koenig Krieg, its the way Freddy would have played it!

—description from the publisher

Two players challenge each other in this quick, fun game of sparring DieMinions. DieMinions are dice shaped creatures that are the henchmen, or Minions, of a group of larger dungeon monsters.

Each player has 6 cards (identical to the other players), along with a set of 24 cards called a "Deck-A-Dice". Players choose a DieMinion card to play from their hand, face down, simultaneously, then reveal their choices and proceed to battle each other using the "Deck-A-Dice" to roll their attack.

This is designed to be a simple filler game, taking 10-15 minutes to play with 1 minute of setup time.

—description from the designer

AracKhan Wars is a Tactical Card Game where 2 to 4 players battle for dominance in Epic Duels. 
Take control of a province of AracKhan and defy your opponent on the Battlefield !! Launch the assault with your army of 23 cards! Cast spells! Place your cards wisely and counter the plans of your opponent. Your skills as a strategist will be as critical as the value of your cards. There can be only one victor at the end of 9th and final round!

Game Mechanics Synthesis:

     2 players will compete, each will choose  a deck color, they will build their 23 card deck, with a maximum value of 125 points.
     The decks must be properly shuffled, this will constitute your pile.
     Unless the players are dueling on a mat, they will define a game zone that will become the Battlefield.
     In AracKhan Wars, on the Battlefield every card placed face down (during the Placement Phase) or moved (during the Activation Phase) must be or end its movement, adjacent to another card.
     Adjacent meaning bordering one of the 4 edges of an ally or enemy card and in an available space.
     After the end of the 9th round, each player adds the values on the cards present on the Battlefield with a token of his or her color. The player with the highest added values wins the game.


AracKhan Wars features the artworks of the following artists:
Aaron Florento, Angga Dwipanaya, Adam Gleba, Ekaterina Poliakowa, Gabrielle Ragusi, Anastassia Grigorieva, Milica Celikovic, Ramon Puasa JR, JB Casacop, Elie Rigault, Adam Gleba, CJ Centeno, Brian Valeza, Andrew Chou, Pandu Mahardika, Joshua Raphael, Le Rastislav, Marve Bärg, Ryan Van Dongen, Narendra B Adi, Ferdinand Ladera, Alexander Kozachenko, Inna Vjuzhanina, Ramza Ardyputra, Vlad Botos, Leo Aveiro, Rafael Gorniak.

—description from the publisher

KIAR (Kings In A Row) is a simple abstract game played on a 4 hex board where the central hex is not used. Each player has 15 pieces. Take turns placing your own colour pieces on any free hex on the board. When you have three in a row you can crown any one of the three into a king by placing a piece on top of another, a mechanic inspired by the abstract boardgame LOT. The other two pieces of the original line of three must be removed from the board but can be played again. Once you have crowned the piece, if it is adjacent to an opponents king and you can jump over that king into a free space behind you can then remove the opponents king. This is the only occasion a piece can move on the board after being placed. A newly crowned piece can only jump another King. A single piece cannot be jumped. Return the jumped pieces to your opponent. Continue playing until a player has managed to reach a winning position of creating three Kings In A Row (KIAR) or until a player runs out of pieces. In that scenario the first player who cannot make a move due to not having any pieces left loses.

—description from the designer

When the days are getting shorter, little creatures range through the forest in search of valuable food trying to prepare for the winter. In Lyttle Wood, you try to collect points by combining gang and prey cards. Be aware that everyone is seeking for the most valuable food and the competition in the forest is huge. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins and will be the king or queen of the forest!

—description from the publisher

Each turn in The #UpsideDownChallenge Game, the active player draws a challenge card, which might be an individual challenge or a group challenge. Whoever the active player is dons glasses that flip their vision upside down, then they try to do what they've been challenged to do, such as giving someone a high five, pouring water into a glass, or drawing a picture.

You win and lose points along the way, and whoever first collects six points wins!

1. The core gameplay of War with Goblins is the fight between different troops and conquering cities. Each player has at his disposal many units, which he can successively introduce to the game if he has only the right number of ducats. About 24 different types of troops take part in the war. On the obverse of the board we have the land map and on the reverse the second, sea map. The game has climatic, oldschool fantasy graphics, perfectly depicting a magical world in which humans coexist with goblins.

2. This is a turn-based war game. The board is divided into areas. Each of them has one type of terrain assigned to it. Terrain affects the movement of units as well as their combat strength. There are 12 cities on the board, a number of villages and dungeons, which are the source of money (ducats).
Each player in his turn can buy troops on the board (in the form of tokens), moves them, occupy areas and fights battles. The strength of the units, their HP, and partly the dice decide about the result of the clashes. Units can be combined into larger groups, up to 4 units.

3. The player who has the most cities after 6, 8 or 10 rounds wins.

—description from the designer

Guide your frogs across the pond and block other players from doing the same in Froggit. The first player to get their entire frog family to the other side wins, but when your opponents are awarded fish, they can send you back to the start!

Flexible thinking, clever planning, and the chance to thwart your opponents make this a fun and exciting game!

—description from the publisher

Top Spot is a multi-player card game for 3-5 players that features cards with holes. Players score points and win rounds by strategically combining cards to create value. The player with the highest point total at the end wins.

—description from the publisher

"The people sitting around your table have been lying to you. They are actually the most powerful leaders of industry the world has ever seen, with massive stockpiles of resources and weapons, probably hiding somewhere in their basement. Can you trust them? Can they trust you? I don't know, but I'm pickin' up some strange vibes. Could be that tuna I ate earlier..."

Nuke? the Card Game puts players in the hot-seat as billionaires and world leaders with two simple goals: 1) to make more many than they ever did, 2) to not get blowed up.

You will be embodying a richer you, and over the course of 3 rounds, collecting sets of commodities to ensure a profitable asset portfolio. How will you accomplish this? Through trade negotiations of course! In real-time, you and your friends will be making deals as shrewdly as possible, but it's in the follow through that your true colours will show. Should you deal honestly and fulfill your end of the bargain? Or should you forsake your responsibility and send the all-dreaded nuke? See, here's the trick: all of the cards that are traded remain hidden until the end of the round. And then, just when you think you're all set to make a fat stack of dough... you flip your cards to reveal 3 nukes! Thanks guys, thanks a lot.

To add a little more chaos into the mix you'll receive a secret identity, and in the second round you'll get 2, and in the third round, 3. Talk about split personalities... These Identity cards might give you a scoring bonus or even a powerful single-use ability to whap out at the most opportune time. Pretty neat! Now it's time for you to put your power of persuasion to the test. But even for the shrewdest shark, at the end of the day the only question that remains is this: should you be a stable and trustworthy friend, or should you send a Nuke?

—description from the designer

With a chamfered edge finish on the finest of exposed apple ply, a textured green pitch, artisan crafted nets, and sturdy designed playing pieces, the Binho Classic has a beautiful playability and is of supreme quality. Each game comes with two regular marbles, two scoring pieces, and two  yellow/red playing cards.

The Binho Classic board consists of 10 players and 1 goal on each side of the field surrounded by elastic Binho Bands for more creativity and scoring angles. Experience the flickin' magic with your fam and friends today.

Binho Board is a turn based tabletop soccer type board game that brings the unexpected actions and player controlled events right to your living room. With elastic bands surrounding the field, create angles and find openings throughout the 10 defenders that are spaced on each side of the board. The game is played to 7 and can be played 1 on 1 or 2 on 2.

COLD WAR3! Rules for Modern Warfare 1960-1990 allows you to field a tabletop army (and fight with it) in 6mm, 15mm or even 20mm (or any combination thereof!) from the early Cold war right up to it's finish in 1990.


     This comprehensive rulebook includes TWO complete orders of battle for the American and Soviet forces split into three sections:
         1960-'70 -Early; 
         1970-'80 -Middle; and
         1980-'90 -Late COLD WAR if you will.
    



     This book covers rules for armoured, mechanised and infantry assaults, movement, firing, night fighting, engineers, scouts, snipers, medics and battlefield recovery. 
     It also includes rules for modern anti-tank weapons from the AT-3 through to the TOW II and Milan ATGM's as well as modern armour such as ERA (explosive reactive armour), Composite (such as Chobham) and things such as side skirts and improvised armour.



     Rules for artillery, including all of the sub-munitions such as FASCAM (scaterable mines), DPICM (boosted rounds), Copperhead (guided rounds) and High Explosive, chemical and smoke rounds as well!



     Rules for air support and even surface-to-air-missiles, aircraft firing on ground targets, straffing runs, bombing runs and avoiding ground fire are all included as well as such ordinance as smart bombs, high explosives, rocket pods and even napalm! Loitering, air to air combat and re-arming are also included. Rules for helicopters, gunships and even medical evacuation are covered in depth as well.



     A comprehensive air craft armoury lists is included covering everything from the A1 Skyhawk to the A-10, the F14, F15, F16 and even F-18, the F-104 through to the Phantom and even A6 crusaders!For the Russians we have the Mig-15 through to Mig-29, the Su-25, Su-11 and even Su-7 ground attack, the Tu-11 and Tu-95 bombers to bring added carnage to the battlefield!



     Optional rules can take your COLD WAR 3! Battles to new, hotter, levels with the inclusion of chemical, biological and even nuclear effects are covered as well as on-table explosions, loitering times, decontamination, detection and even on-table nuclear explosions!



     Modern armour from the T34/85 through to the T-80u, the M48a1 right through to the M1a2 and all manner of armoured vehicles in between such as the BTR family of wheeled APC's, the BMP-1 and BMP-2 and the ubiquitous M-113 family of armoured personnel carriers and the modern M2 and M3 Bradleys!


These rules are compatible with other popular 15mm tabletop games such as TY and FoW as well as other titles produced by Dean Wilson.

—description from the publisher

Hex Command Gunpowder are rules for miniature gaming the horse and musket era.
Also includes rules for the Pike and Shotte era.

These rules for miniature war gaming combine board game mechanics with miniatures, where the basic concepts and intent of the rules is to be shared or made common with other rules in the Hex Command System: Ancients, Mechanized and more.
Where possible, as many common concepts and procedures were to be incorporated so that once a particular set was learned, the other rules would find the same intentions.

Hex Command avoids complex issues of movement and measuring due to the use of a hex grid, and infantry regiments do not consist of multiple stands and are not concerned with formations. When a is "Fatigued" it means it has reached the limit of encountering obstacles and efforts such as melee.

To win this game, players must observe the tactical reserve, maneuvering the enemy, and supported combat. Use of Game Cards keep players from being all-knowing and all-seeing above the game table... the fog of war element.

—description from the introduction of the book from the publisher

These rules for miniature war gaming combine board game mechanics with miniatures, where the basic concepts and intent of the rules is to be shared or made common with other rules in the Hex Command System: Ancients, Mechanized and more.
Where possible, as many common concepts and procedures were to be incorporated so that once a particular set was learned, the other rules would find the same intentions.

Hex Command avoids complex issues of movement and measuring due to the use of a hex grid.

To win this game, players must observe the tactical reserve, maneuvering the enemy, and supported combat. Use of Game Cards keep players from being all-knowing and all-seeing above the game table... the fog of war element.

—description from the publisher

Recruit Companions, Learn Knowledge, and take Action to create a unique and formidable Guild capable of battling back ferocious creatures to reclaim the Kingdom!

GuildCraft is a deckbuilding, tableau-building fantasy sandbox game for 2-4 Players. Set in a Medieval Fantasy setting, each Player controls a Guild that they will build up and customize over the course of the game.

Players are tasked with a mission from the King to go forth into the world to conquer and claim new territory for the Kingdom.  Beware though, the lands beyond the Castle grounds are crawling with dangerous, ferocious creatures, intent on cutting down anyone who encroaches into their domains.

During their Turn, Players will play and use Cards to venture forth and discover new lands, Gather valuable Resources, and eliminate the deadly Creatures that plague the Kingdom.  The Resources that they Gather can be used to Hire helpful Companions, Learn  Knowledge, or Develop powerful Actions to aid them in their Quest.

The Player with the greatest Guild at the End Game is the victor!

—description from the designer

Pocket Investigations is a series of "escape boxes", i.e. cooperative board games that are based on escape games, but playable at home.

The scenario Apollo 22, the players lead the investigation on a mission to the moon and try to start restart the space shuttle.

Pocket Investigations is a series of "escape boxes", i.e. cooperative investigation board games that are based on escape games, with real items for clues, and playable at home.

In this scenario, the famous Gang des Casinos recruits new talents... Will you be the next? Receive the "robber kit" and simulate the heist of Casino Krysos in Monte-Carlo!

Pocket Investigations is a series of "escape boxes", i.e. cooperative investigation board games that are based on escape games, with real items for clues, and playable at home.

In this scenario, Santa Claus' memory is no longer what it used to be...: he forgot his bank account details and can't log in to buy his Christmas gifts. Will you help him recover his lost information? Merry Christmas is a light initiation scenario to discover Pocket Investigations.

Latte Throwdown is a 2-4 player Dice Pool/Dice Rolling and placement game. You are a Barista competing in a Latte Art Throwdown competition. Complete and score the best latte pours before the competition does! You score points by matching your dice to the combination of dice shown on the Latte Cards. The first Barista to reach 20 points wins! Use your Barista powers strategically and beware of the other Baristas, who will try to creatively snatch the best designs ahead of you. Hold that pitcher steady, keep an eye on the other Baristas and don’t spill your milk!

—description from the publisher
